results.title: Circular and squint bays, gable knees, corbelling, tile creasing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
Shows various methods of bricklaying including the trammel method for circular walls; templet method; obtuse angled wall, use of squint bricks, purpose made and hand cut; knee of oversailing brickwork; angle cuts for gable bricks; corbels for wall plate; corbelling for attached pier; tile creasing with brick-on-edge finish.
results.title_for_label: Circular and squint bays, gable knees, corbelling, tile creasing

results.title: Circles of learning
results.creator_credit: University of Minnesota, Roger Johnson, David W. Johnson and Patricia Roy
results.brief_description: Provides an introduction to co-operative learning strategies in the primary and postprimary school. Shows an across-the-curriculum approach that develops the co-operative learning skills children need to work in small groups. Though set in the US context, it has applicability to the local classroom situation. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level students.

results.title: Circles II
results.creator_credit: Doris Chase, Perspective Films and King Screen Productions
results.brief_description: Members of the Mary Stanton Dance Ensemble perform in and around huge fibreglass circles designed by artist/filmmaker Doris Chase. A superimposition technique is used on the circles and human forms, which rotate in a of different patterns and colors. The dancers move with, around and through the kinetic sculptures. Music by George Kleinsinger. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Circle of the sun = Le Soleil perdu
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Colin Low
results.brief_description: At the 1961 gathering of the Blood Indians of Alberta the exciting spectacle of the Sun Dance was captured on film for the first time. The film also reflects the predicament of the young generation, those who relinquished their ties with their own people but have not yet found a firm place in a changing world. (Awards include: London, Brussels, Toronto)

results.title: Cipher in the snow
results.creator_credit: Wetzel O. Whitaker, Brigham Young University and Keith J. Atkinson
results.brief_description: A child asks to be let off the school bus - and dies in the snow. Neither students nor teachers know him - his favourite teacher, who barely remembers him - goes to see his parents. In an attempt to write an obituary the teacher reads through the child’s school reports. The people around him changed him into a nobody. Designed for teachers to motivate a concern for the needs of every child.

results.title: Cinesound review. No. 1989. Communications unlimited
results.brief_description: Looks at the electronics industry in Australia, showing the manufacture of modern electronic equipment. Also gives impressions of the importance of telecommunications in society.

results.title: Cinesound Review [compilation]
results.brief_description: A compilation of cinemagazine items: 1. Redex Air Trial begins. 2. Annual oddities: dog collects newspapers. 3. Australia first helicopter test. 4. Deaf and dumb - but they can fight! 5. Romeo and Juliet backyard style. 6. RU Fijians defeat Australia 18-16 2nd test. 7. Redex cars ready for road 9600 mile journey. 8. Lae wrecked by war rebuilds modern New Guinea. 9. Opera rehearsal in open air. 10. Spotting the news: Sydney synagogue. 11. World champion oyster eater - 480 in an hour. 12. Spotting the news: NSW University of Technology officially opened; 1st Australian girl born armless to have artificial limb (New York Hospital). 13. Mildura harvest train brings raisin festival. 14. Vic and NSW head of river. 15. Fun of the fair: Royal Adelaide Show. 16. Spotting the news: Clement Atlee visits Australia; 2GB’s Search for a white crow; Antarctic hits the sub-tropical far north coast of NSW. 17. Heartbreaker: Johnny Ray fascinates females. 18. Feeding time at the zoo. 19. Three services in battle display. 20. Pre-fab houses for flood areas. 21. Royal Easter Show Sydney - features boxing booth. 22. Melbourne’s Royal Show (1954). 23. Female festival: marching girls right in step. 24. Amateurs compete for world’s billiards championship. 25. The bare facts on Gypsy Rose Lee.
